_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Coastal Pacific Food Distributors uses anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration of goods for distribution.  Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical used at this facility that is subject to the CalARP program or federal RMP requirements.

This facility recognizes the hazards associated with the use of highly hazardous chemicals.  As a reflection of our policy to adhere to all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations, we submit this plan to address the hazards inherent with the use of ammonia.  Our program addresses safety precautions regarding the handling and operation of this covered system as well as proper training for those who operate and maintain the system.  The company training policy requires that all employees will be properly trained for a job position before assignment to that job.

Our accidental release prevention program is clearly defined by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program for this facility.  This prevention program follows industry-recommended standards for preventing unnecessary human exposures and notification of the local emergency responders.  This EAP also includes a specific protocol for responding to an ammonia release and assigns an Emergency Coordinator to implement the response.  This Plan is current and updated as required by law and conforms to the requirements for an Emergency Action Plan as per 29 CFR ? 1910.38(a).

This facility has also coordinated with the local emergency responders and will maintain close contact to ensure that the responders are familiar with the system and with the general safety and accidental release program at our plant.

It is the policy of this facility to devote the time, energy, and capital toward maintaining prevention and response programs appropriate to the inherent dangers with the use of hazardous chemicals.
 
THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

The Stationary Source

 The Coastal Pacific Foo

ency showers and eyewash stations
The extent of involvement in the operation of the refrigeration system by employees is limited to daily monitoring and recording.  The maintenance of the system will be contracted to a qualified refrigeration contractor.

The facility maintains an Emergency Action Plan for response to ammonia releases.  The Plan includes notification and evacuation protocols.

THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

This facility complies with the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program and OSHAA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) Program.  Key prevention steps taken by this facility to maintain safety are outlined in the PSM Program.  These include the description of all system and equipment information, process hazard analysis, operator training, contractor qualification, operating procedures, pre-startup safety review, hot work permitting, management of change, mechanical integrity, incident investigation, compliance audits, and emergency response.

Those who operate, maintain, or supervise the system will be trained to understand the principles of ammonia refrigeration and ammonia properties, an understanding of the process equipment and proper operating and maintenance procedures, recognition of abnormal conditions and the steps to correct deviations, and emergency shutdown procedures as appropriate to the level of involvement each employee will have with the process.  Contractors that perform maintenance or that design changes to the system will be qualified by the facility based upon their experience and safety record before being selected to provide such services.

The general safety program includes hazardous communication, forklift operation, first aid, emergency response, and additional programs as necessary to maintain a safe operation.

THE FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

As defined by EPA, there have been no recordable accidents.

THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Employe

es are trained to understand the requirements of the Emergency Action Plan.  The Emergency Action Plan includes release notification for emergency responders and the procedures for evacuation.  The Emergency Coordinator implements the response in coordination with the local emergency responders (i.e. the fire department).  It is the policy and practice to conduct evacuation drills twice per year.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was performed as required prior to initial startup of the system.  The PHA team developed a list of recommendations to improve safety by reducing potential hazards of the process.  All recommendations were implemented, deemed unnecessary since no improvements to safety would result, or planned for implementation at a later date.  Upcoming events include:

? Training of employees to conduct daily monitoring of system conditions
? Consideration of provision of backup power for the public address system
? Minor hardware changes to enhance accessibility
